Sanskrit: cāpālacaitya, Pali: cāpālacaitya. The Mahāparinibbānasutta 《遊行經》 describes the Buddha's visit Cāpāla Shrine, located near the city of Vesālī. It was during this visit to the Cāpāla Shrine that the Buddha announced that he would soon pass away achieving Parinirvāṇa (T 1, Scroll 2; Dīgha Nikāya 16; BL 'Cāpālacaitya'; FGDB '離車毘'; Muller 1888, 'Licchavi').

Sanskrit: uruvilvā, Pali: uruvelā, Japanese: Urubinra. Uruvilvā miterally means 'great bank of sand' in Sanskrit. It is located near the Nairanjana River 尼連禪. The Bodhisattva practiced asceticism in Uruvilvā for six years (BL 'Uruvilvā'; FGDB '優樓頻螺聚落'). The Mahāparinibbānasutta 《遊行經》 describes the Buddha visiting to Uruvilvā 鬱鞞羅 (T 1, Scroll 2; Dīgha Nikāya 16).

Sanskrit equivalent: sārnāth; located 13 kilometres north-east of Vārāṇasī, in Uttar Pradesh, India. It is the location of 鹿野苑 Mṛgadāva 'Deer Park' where the Buddha first taught the Dharma, described as the first turning of the Dharma Wheel (BL 'Sārnāth'; FGDB '鹿野苑').
